title: Jennifer Aniston hates being set up on dates as she talks single life
text:
Don’t matchmake her, guys (Picture: FilmMagic)

Jennifer Aniston isn’t a fan of being set up on dates by her matching friends and we totally get it.

The Friends star has opened up on her love life, insisting she is perfectly happy single.

Can we please just appreciate this goddess without bringing the ‘sad Jen’ rhetoric back? Thank you.

The actress has been single and not ready to mingle since splitting with former husband, Justin Theroux, in 2017, and has more than enough on her plate without adding another man to things.

Asked whether she was enjoying being single, the 50-year-old actress recently said: ‘Yeah, and I’m very busy. For now. I’m promoting [The Morning Show]. I’m prepping for next season.’

See, busy.

Jennifer and Justin split in 2017 (Picture: Broadimage/REX )

Jen just isn’t interested in dating at the moment, because she has too much on her plate with her career, and she definitely has no interest in letting her friends set her up on a date either.

At the thought of a blind date, Jennifer said she ‘hates it’ when people try to play matchmaker for her.

Chatting to Howard Stern on SiriusXM, she added: ‘Hey, listen, I just don’t like being set up. I don’t like it. I hate it.’

Last year, sources said the star wasn’t ‘concerned about dating’ following her split from Justin, two years after marrying in 2015.

The insider said: ‘She isn’t concerned about dating. She is happy to focus on work.

‘She doesn’t even talk about [Justin] anymore. She doesn’t keep up with what he does. She is focusing on her own life.’

And fair play to her.

Meanwhile, Jennifer – who was also married to Brad Pitt from 2000 to 2005 – previously revealed she is ‘not heartbroken’ over her separation from 48-year-old actor Justin.

She said: ‘The misconceptions are “Jen can’t keep a man,” and “Jen refuses to have a baby because she’s selfish and committed to her career.” Or that I’m sad and heartbroken. First, with all due respect, I’m not heartbroken.

‘And second, those are reckless assumptions. No one knows what’s going on behind closed doors. No one considers how sensitive that might be for my partner and me. They don’t know what I’ve been through medically or emotionally.’
